course_title: Topics: Historical Analysis: Workers in the Americas
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 35 / Seats Avail: 35Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes: What is work? Who are workers? What does it mean to work for a living? And how does work affect other areas of one's life? One's family? Expectations? Politics? Leisure? This course explores these and other questions bearing on 'work' and 'workers' by examining various laboring populations during the 19th and 20th centuries in countries across the Americas. We will focus on particular case studies, eras, and industries in select countries of this large geographic region (certainly including the US, Brazil, Mexico, and Colombia). And we will thoroughly engage the concept of class. This broad, comparative framework will provide a rich understanding of the range of experiences men and women had with phenomena like slavery, industrialization, and domestic labor. It will also deepen our appreciation for how these people responded to their situations.
course_description: An introductory course on the nature and methods of history. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
